If anybody want to recreate this but doesnt has sodium metal here is an alternate way to do this:
Electrolysis of concentrated NaCl solution with copper wire as a cathode that is fully insulated only open in the end submerged into mercury. Electrolyse for 10 minutes and the mercury is taken out of the electrolysis solution and added into NH4Cl solution. It does the same reaction as shown in the video.

Theory on this: The Na/Hg amalgam is a metallic system with reactive sodium. NH3 (anhydrous) and sodium metal can typically form a solvated electron system with a blue-ish color wherein the sodium and electron dissociate (with a crown ether, you can capture the Na+ ions and increase stability) - however, water gives a route to consume the electron via H+ + e- -> H2

What I found interesting here is that it looks like your amalgam actually turns a little bit blue, so I am wondering if you are creating a meta-stable solvated electron system that is reacting out once HCl is added to complex up the Na, and the bubbles you are seeing are (at least in part) H2 from consumption of the free electron by free protons from the water and acid.

Cool video. You could learn much more about this material if you would control the concentration of NH4Cl/HCl/NH4OH and the temperature somewhat more accurately. The pH will have an influence on the reaction of the solution with the sodium in the amalgam, the concentration of the NH4+ on the rate the ammonium amalgam can form, and the temperature on the overall reaction rates and the balance between multiple equilibria. Since it seems to be a complicated (and utterly cool) network of reactions, not only it is important to control these to achieve a nice and stable piece of amalgam, but also essential for understanding what’s going on.

I suggest you make sodium amalgam with as high a sodium content as is reasonably stable, Prepare a a strong solution of ammonium chloride then chill it to about 10 degrees C.. It shold not freeze. Put the cold na amalgam in the icy cold ammonium chloride aolution and let it sit and react. Neutral sodium atoms will reduce the amonnium ions to neutral ammonium which will dissolve in the mercury as ammonium metal and the sodium will become sodium ions and you will have a lump of ammonium amalgam in a cold solution of sodium chloride. Keep it well bellow freezing if you want it to be stable. Ammmonium amalgam is a strong reducing agent like an alkali metal amalgam but it only reacts slowly with cold water, You can also prepare ammonium amalgam by preparing a cold solution of ammonium carbonate and electrolysing it with a pool of mercury as the cathode. Keep in mind that pure metallic ammonium does exist at high pressure, You compress ammonia with hydrogen until it becomes metallic, There is suspicion that large amounts of it exists deep in the atmospheres of outer olanets. It might remain stable at ordinary pressures if it is kept cold enough. You can get similar results with quaternariammonium salts. In particular, if you electrolise twtramethylammonium hydroxide solution (cold!) with a mercury cathode you will get the amalgam. It is possible to dissolve alkali metals in cold ammonia so they form deep blue solutions with powerful reducing properties.It is also possible to form such solutions using quaternarium amonnium compounnds. they are powerful reducing agents too. It is believed that they contain a positive ion with a free electron forming what are called electride salts, I have not heard this being done with plain ammonia but who knows? Hey @NileRed I'm not qualified at all for this conclusion, but I believe what happened is the following:

The ammonia and the mercury didn't form an amalgam.

It just aired the mercury. You know, like when you cook dough and the yeast fills it with little CO2 pockets, instead here it's probably either hydrogen pockets or nitrogen pockets. Or maybe both. I think it works exactly like when you hydrogenate oils, it bestows a solid or solid-like consistency, but since instead of dealing with a complex molecule, like in the case of unsaturated fats, you are dealing with elemental mercury, it doesn't have the bond stability to hold on its own.

If my theory is right, then after a long while (or maybe a couple of good shakes in a vial, idk) the mercury should return to normal once all the bubbles go away.
It might be wierd but I could watch that change back and forth all day and not get bored.

When the acid is added straight away it sinks because it is much more dense than ammonia solution - which is itself less dense than water. When the sodium amalgam has been allowed to react for a time before adding the hydrochloric acid, a concentration of sodium hydroxide has started to build up which increases the density of the solution, perhaps locally around the amalgam, which prevents the acid from sinking directly onto the amalgam and gives it time to mix and react with the ammonia. This would account for the observed differences in reaction.

It would therefore seem like a good idea to try reacting the amalgam with ammonium chloride solution of various concentrations. (There's still two-thirds of the video to play as I type this.)

Ehhh... the issue is you can't answer the underlying mechanics of the reaction.

Both mercury and ammonium can alter chemical form to accommodate electrons, and sodium chemistry is rather susceptible to nitrogen reactions.

The form that you're betting on is attributing all the reactivity to mercury, but I think that's just what makes this reaction toxic.

Main mercury chemistry concerns look something like this
Hg >> Hg I <> Hg II

However...
Nitrogen, especially in the form of ammonia, can form it's own catalytic series. We don't see it often because ammonia and amines are viewed as desirable end products, but this is the basis of a lot of organic nitrogen chemistry.

Those reactions look something like this:
Ammonium >> Primary Amine <> secondary amine << tertiary amine.


Now, there are times that the process doesn't involve organic compounds, so "Amine" might not be correct. The real issue here is whether the nitrogen atom is bound to 1 mercury atom or two.
Nitrogen bound to multiple mercury atoms would indicate that the mercury charge is stable, meaning most reactivity would come from the reactivity of the nitrogen.

The fact that adding nitrate disrupts the amalgum as quickly as it does is good evidence that the nitrogen atom on the ammonium complex is the species reacting and changing.
Nitrate and ammonium tends to form nitrogen gas and water.

Out of curiosity - did you try adding solid Ammonium Chloride to the Sodium Amalgam? Would be interesting to see if the reaction still happens fast enough without the solvent (My guess is no, but who knows). Different solvents might also yield different results (e.g. glycerine, which apparently dissolves NH4Cl quite well).

A solution of ammonium chloride in liquid ammonia also sounds like an interesting candidate, although it requires a much more complex setup. Would be very interesting to see if we observe the formation of ammonium amalgam or the usual reaction of sodium with liquid ammonia, or both (Or if the amalgam just freezes and nothing happens).

I think that it is likely that the ammonium radical which is formed is able to solidify the mercury because calculation have shown that ammonium radicals behave much like a sodium atom. This includes the ionisation potential and electron affinity, but the radius is of course larger that that of sodium and more closely resembles that of cesium (1). But cesium amalgams are, as all alkali metal amalgams, also solid (2). Therefore I think that your first hypothesis is most likely.

1. https://www.chemistryworld.com/news/ammonium-radical-is-atomic-pretender/3000331.article
2. http://zfn.mpdl.mpg.de/data/Reihe_B/48/ZNB-1993-48b-0011.pdf (not a great source but does mention the fact that all amalgams crystallize)

PS. The ionisation potentials for the ammonium radical seem to differ significantly per study, but are always between that of sodium and cesium. The one I quoted which denotes a potential similar to that of sodium seems to be the most recent.

ok, after some cursory research and a little thought, let's think about what's going on. We start initially with Na . Hg amalgum and with some ammonium salt (NH4+/x-) where X is some relatively inert halie or pseudohalide - then it forms some sort of NH4 . Hg amalgum. So in this reaction the halide is a spectator, but we have a redox reaction between sodium and ammonium, going to a sodium salt (NaX), and Hg . NH4. However the NH4 is not really a radical like you suggested. Due to the fact all the valence orbitals are full there's no where for that extra electron to go. Instead what happens here is there is NH4+ and a "free" electorn (e-) which is dissociated throughout the mercury.

My guess is that this amalgum or the sodium one you started with could be potentially useful electron donors in a variety of redox reactions, as working with free electron donors (such as sodium metal) is extrodinarily volitile.

Anyway, thanks for letting me flex my chemistry brain a little bit. I haven't thought about this stuff in over a decade <3 Keep up the good work!

Physicist here. Is this possibly a metastable state? The degredation of the NH4 radical within the amalgam structure is slower than one would expect under normal conditions (I guess within the amalgam it becomes semi-metallic as NH4+ with e- loosely bound, with the Hg keeping the NH4 apart from one another?). Then the evolution of this compound can be described as a phase change independently of the chemical reaction.

Measuring the timescales according to how long the amalgams float is probably a red herring; that measures how much GAS is present in the material, not how much NH4-Hg amalgam. There could be very much more in one or the other sample. It's very likely a pure coincidence that the float times were the same.

I think further investigation with temperature control would be interesting. The Hg-NH4 amalgam forms quickly at high temperatures and assumes structure before any NH4 can decay; allowing the Na to react with H2O first makes the reaction even more vigorous (acid-base heating?) The main problem is that I think you need to form the amalgam quickly, then rapidly cool it before it decays. If you can literally freeze some solid with LN2, you might have time to observe the stability of the NH4 radical.

You want to know something really interesting? Normally you can't produce sodium metal by electrolyzing saltwater, for obvious reasons, since it's salt WATER. BUT a sodium amalgam with a low percentage of sodium, may be more like alka seltzer. So if you put a heavy current through a mercury cathode, it will pick up some sodium content and eventually reach equilibrium where the rate at which sodium gets reduced and dissolves into the mercury is the same at which it reacts with the electrolyte. This will still be only a few percent, but theoretically you could also refine the sodium out of the mercury, thus making sodium metal out of electrolysis of saltwater at room temperature.

The reason it doesn't work with the nitrate might be because of the strong oxidising nature of nitrate ions. I imagine NH4 radicals would be very good reducing agents and the nitrate ions might just oxidise them as soon as they are formed.
